item.title: Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Trims Valeant Stake to 8.5%
item.description: Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square trimmed its stake in Valeant Pharmaceuticals to 8.5%, a move the hedge fund said was related to year-end tax planning.

item.title: Venezuela Currency Bust Fuels Plastic Surgery Boom Boom
item.description: As a side effect of stringent currency controls, Venezuela has become low-cost plastic surgery hub, drawing poor women from across the border in Brazil who want a Miss Venezuela beauty treatment on a Cinderella budget.

item.title: DOJ Probes Blue Bell's Response to Listeria Contamination
item.description: The U.S. Justice Department has launched a criminal investigation into Blue Bell Creameries over a listeria contamination of its ice cream earlier this year that was linked to three deaths and multiple other illnesses.

item.title: Yoga Guru's Remedies Take on Global Brands in India
item.description: Baba Ramdev—one of India’s most celebrated yoga gurus—has built a consumer-goods empire that sells products based on traditional Indian medicine, and international companies are taking notice.

item.title: Indian Drugmaker Takes Second Shot With Its Generic Nexium
item.description: Dr. Reddy’s Laboratories relaunched its popular generic version of the heartburn remedy Nexium in a new color after a U.S. court last month agreed with AstraZeneca’s objections to the old one.

item.title: The Market's Latest Comeback Story: Biotech Stocks
item.description: After an autumn selloff, the Nasdaq Biotechnology Index has rallied 18% from its 2015 low in September, and is now up 13% for the year.

item.title: Valeant CEO Is on Medical Leave
item.description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International said Chief Executive J. Michael Pearson, who the company last week confirmed was hospitalized with a severe case of pneumonia, is on medical leave effective immediately.

item.title: Health Insurers to Face Fines for Not Correcting Doctor Directories
item.description: New regulations, set to take effect on Friday, will allow the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services to fine insurers up to $25,000 per beneficiary for errors in Medicare Advantage directories.

item.title: Brazil Approves Sanofi's Dengue Vaccine
item.description: Sanofi Pasteur, the vaccine division of France’s Sanofi, said it has secured approval from Brazilian authorities to market its dengue fever vaccine amid an explosion of cases.

item.title: Two KaloBios Board Members Quit After Shkreli Departure
item.description: KaloBios Pharmaceuticals said two of its board members have resigned, continuing fallout in the wake of former Chief Executive Martin Shkreli’s recent arrest on securities-fraud charges.

item.title: Year in Review: Top 10 Health Issues of 2015
item.description: From the perils of processed meats to soaring drug prices and breakthroughs in cancer treatment, here are some of the past year’s biggest health stories.

item.title: At Theranos, Strategies and Snags
item.description: At Theranos, the blood-testing ambition of founder Elizabeth Holmes has long collided with technological problems, according to former employees of the Silicon Valley startup, company emails and complaints filed with federal regulators.

item.title: GM Urged to Make Air Bags Standard in Mexico
item.description: GM is facing calls to add air bags as standard equipment on its popular compact cars in Mexico, mirroring broader pressure on auto makers to provide basic safety equipment even when governments don’t mandate it.

item.title: From Beef to Beans, Farmers Weather Worst of El Niño
item.description: Higher temperatures and lower rainfall in eastern Australia, Southeast Asia and India are affecting industries from Australia’s traditional cattle ranching to Vietnam’s coffee crop.

item.title: New Outbreak Chills Chipotle's Rebound
item.description: Restaurant chain Chipotle is stuck in marketing limbo, unable to restart customer appeals while it awaits a declaration of an end of a series of foodborne disease outbreaks tied to its outlets.

item.title: New Risks at Rural Hospitals
item.description: Financial incentives are leading small rural hospitals to perform more surgeries, posing new risks for patients.

item.title: Faster Medical Attention With App
item.description: In Jersey City, the nonprofit United Rescue is investing nearly $2 million to train and equip volunteers to be dispatched to medical emergencies through a smartphone app.

item.title: Valeant CEO Hospitalized With Severe Pneumonia
item.description: The head of troubled pharmaceutical company Valeant Pharmaceuticals International has been hospitalized for severe pneumonia.

item.title: New Health Programs for Elderly Poor Make Rocky Start
item.description: A federal experiment to rein in health spending and improve care for people on both Medicare and Medicaid has seen enrollment fall short of expectations, as patients prove reluctant to switch to the new programs.

item.title: KaloBios Faces Nasdaq Delisting in Shkreli's Wake
item.description: KaloBios Pharmaceuticals said it had received a delisting letter from the Nasdaq Stock Market, days after former Chief Executive Martin Shkreli was charged with securities fraud.

item.title: HealthCare.gov Users Hit 8.2 Million
item.description: A late surge of insurance applications and automatic renewals pushed the number of people using HealthCare.gov to 8.2 million through Dec. 19, federal officials said.

item.title: Hillary Clinton Calls for $2 Billion for Alzheimer's
item.description: Hillary Clinton rolled out a plan aimed at finding a cure for Alzheimer’s through a dramatic increase in government research spending, a project that she would underwrite partly through tax-code changes that shift the burden to wealthier Americans.

item.title: Spreading Virus Adds to Brazil's Woes
item.description: Brazil is in the grips of yet another crisis: a fast-spreading virus some health officials are linking to thousands of cases of infant brain damage and 40 related deaths this year.

item.title: Valeant Deal With Walgreens Has Unusual Twist
item.description: Valeant’s distribution deal with Walgreens has a twist that allows the drugmaker to repurchase its drugs at the pharmacy without physically taking them back.

item.title: Surge in Prescription Costs Hit Medicare in 2014
item.description: Hefty price increases for a number of prescription drugs contributed to higher spending by the U.S. Medicare program in 2014, according to new government data.

item.title: Why a Drug to Prevent HIV Infection Is in Low Demand
item.description: Public-health officials are pushing for wider use of a drug that has proved effective at preventing HIV infection, but some AIDS organizations are lobbying against it.

item.title: Martin Shkreli Says Drug-Price Hikes Led to Arrest
item.description: Former pharmaceutical executive Martin Shkreli says he was targeted for much-criticized price increases and an over-the-top public persona.

item.title: Norwegian Biotech Flags Evidence for Efficacy of 'Kick and Kill' HIV Treatment
item.description: A Norwegian biotechnology firm said it had the first evidence of real promise in a new approach widely considered to be a potential cure for HIV, prompting both cautious optimism and skepticism from experts.

item.title: U.S. Probes Theranos Complaints
item.description: U.S. health regulators are investigating complaints about laboratory and research practices at Theranos by two former employees of the blood-testing startup company.

item.title: Bayer in Venture With Gene-Editing Startup
item.description: Germany’s Bayer will establish a joint venture with gene-editing startup Crispr Therapeutics and invest at least $300 million in the partnership in five years, in an effort to develop new medicines based on the emerging technology.

item.title: Glaxo Buys Bristol-Myers Squibb's HIV Assets
item.description: GlaxoSmithKline has agreed to pay Bristol-Myers Squibb up to $1.5 billion to acquire the U.S. company’s pipeline of HIV drugs, a move that will bolster one of the U.K. drug makers’ strongest-performing areas.

item.title: India's Sun Pharmaceutical Gets FDA Warning
item.description: Sun Pharmaceutical’s factory in western India received a warning letter from the FDA, the latest setback for India’s pharmaceutical companies.

item.title: Employers Battle Drug Costs
item.description: Rising drug costs are forcing tough decisions on those footing the bill for much of American health care: employers. The problem is most acute for large, self-insured employers like the University of Minnesota.
